commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. A little unwell?  (6)(4)
2. Lose liquidity, in a way  (4)
3. Salty drink  (3)
4. Place for subs  (5)
5. It may go across the board  (5)


MEDIUM RARE
CLOT
SEA
BENCH
QUEEN

Someone yesterday was asking about whether there was a coincidence when a word is the same between the mini and the main.  I think Vespa today is solid proof that this isn‚Äôt an accident or a coincidence.
UNDER PRESSURE: such a classic. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=a01QQZyl-_I David Bowie and Freddie Mercury now both gone, what a loss. Born too late, I was.

Is this MOSTLY protestant sending His Holiness heartfelt wishes that he is feeling better and will soon be celebrating MASSes again? Oh, POPE, YES!

Thank you, Kate Hawkins and Erica Hsiung Wojcik, for such a lively Monday puzzle‚Äîeasier enough for beginners and engaging enough for pros.
Begging the creators of crosswords to stop using ARI Grande to fill up space. There were at least two other crosswords this week with the same clue.
Fun Monday;   And great column, Sam!!
I though debra was the singular form of debris and this equivalent to a ‚Äúmessing‚Äù on set, knowing nothing about the actor. Happy to get it right though!

A nice Monday with a few unfamiliarities that made me work a bit harder than I'm used to, but the crosses were fair and helped out.

Nice job, Kate and Erica, hopefully this is only the first of many collabs. Thanks!

Good puzzle.

If you want to serve a red wine that goes with virtually anything and isn‚Äôt as heavy as a Cabernet Sauvignon or as delicate as a Pinot noir, then a SYRAH is your go-to. So many excellent wines being bottled in Walla Walla and the Red Mountain AVA these days. Highly recommend.

Nice theme.

I recently saw YEAH RIGHT scrawled across an ad for the Qc gas company (Energir), which was touting how important natural gas is for fighting climate change. 

Understated but effective commentary.

Good to have both Popeye and Yam in a puzzle because there's nothing better than Robin Williams singing:

You don't have to be no fish
To tell when you're flounderin'
What am I? Some kind of barnacles
On the dinghy of life?
I ain't no doctors but I knows
When I'm losin' me patiensk
What am I? Some kind of judge, or a lawyers?
Aw, maybe not but I knows what laws suit's me
So what am I? I ain't no physciscisk
But I knows what matters
What am I? I'm Popeye, the sailor
And I yam what I yam what I
Yam and I yam what I
Yam and that's all that I yam
'cause I yam what I yam
And I gots a lot of muskle
And I only gots one eye
And I never hurts nobodys and
I'll never tell a lie
Tops to me bottoms and me bottoms to me top
And that's the way it is 'till
The day that I drop what am I?
I yam what I yam!

***
Today, I and some friends went to the local deli for lunch, and we all got everything bagels. Everything in the case looked so good that I told them, "Give me an everything with everything." My friend Clyde who's on a diet said, "Give me an everything with nothing." Chas, who always has a hard time making up his mind asked for "an everything with something" and once that was sorted out (a schmear), Laura, who professes not to be picky asked for "an everything with anything." Luckily the counterman knows Laura  and got her what she really wanted, a toasted sesame bagel with a schmear topped with some thinly sliced red onion, green paper and tomato, with a dash of salt and pepper.
The literal antonyms of each word of today‚Äôs theme also likely captures the larger zeitgeist in the US today, unfortunately.

"Did you want me to pick up some deodorant?"
"Sure!"

(I have a Degree in these puns.)

Crossword Revolution Day 27:  YES

Yes

UNDER PRESSURE I YEARN 
To soar like SERENA 
Or GLO like IDINA
To be as RESOLUTE as ARETHA
Or EVEN Awkwafina,
To say ‚ÄúYES, why SURE
I‚Äôm ABLE and PURE!‚Äù
But MOSTLY I‚Äôm MOROSE
Drowning in PATHOS
My heart‚Äôs fire in ASHES,
I‚Äôve given UP on the MASSes.

Open your Eyes,
Dream but don‚Äôt guess.
Your biggest Surprise
Comes after YES.

(The last stanza is the last stanza of Muriel Rukeyser‚Äôs ‚ÄúYes‚Äù)

Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢.
Nice to see Adele Nazeem in the crossword today.
Yup, sure, you betcha.

I liked this puzzle despite not seeing the theme until after I finished the solve. That's probably just because Monday is the one day I try to be speedy. Fun fill! I'll never not like a puzzle that includes Idina Menzel. After seeing her in Wicked on Broadway she became my first celebrity crush :)

In English double negation implies a positive but double positive doesn‚Äôt imply negation ‚Ä¶. said the professor 

Upon which from the back of the class someone called out

YEAH SURE
I guess I don't know how to spell UGLY or GYDDYUP

For the Mini: O-nay a-way...  IXNAY does not mean no. 

For the main: [In the main] felt super dated, but the rest of the puzzle felt pretty fresh. I really loved [Messing around on set?] for DEBRA and the fun fact about the ASCOT [Tie named for a British horse racing venue].  And I liked that SMART/phone/*** combo could have also been jack/phone/***.  Maybe we'll see it later this week. (apparently the word I censored is ok for the puzzle and the column but not ok for the comments)

Oh and every part of an elephant is big lol.

I knew I was in for a good time with this puzzle when I figured out that Messing around the set was Debra, best known from Will & Grace. And any puzzle with Ms ARETHA Franklin is OK by me. Here she is with Think from the Blues Brothers, which started out as an SNL skit, which is on my mind having watched the anniversary special earlier. https://youtu.be/WY66elCQkYk?si=7K44C3CkfNf-JpPB
Super fun! Very smooth downs. I, strangely, had RODEO instead of RANCH and BRATS instead of SNOTS, which was annoying. Thanks!

Who did we see around the RESOLUTE desk? 

UH OH!  

ABLE? 

YEAH, RIGHT......

Strands Thread

Strands #351
‚ÄúSun shade‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

Cast no spoilers please until after the View All Replies button. 

It's those minutes of despair, staring at a board of disconnected letters, followed by the "aha!" moment that keeps me coming back to this pleasant diversion.

Fun puzzle and a pretty smooth solve. For once I actually caught on to the trick fairly early and that just added to the enjoyment of figuring out each of the theme answers. Always glad to see another Katie Hawkins day (and you too, Ms. Wojcik). Of course I have some puzzle finds today. One is a previous puzzle by Ms. Wojcik in collaboration with Matthew Stock. A Wednesday from November 23, 2022. I probably did that one but had forgotten. That one was unusual in that all of theme clues were just a string of colored circles. One clue example was a string of circles - (red, yellow and green) - and the answer was - TRAFFICLIGHT. In another one the clue circles were - (red, yellow, blue, green and black) and the answer was OLYMPICRINGS. Here's the Xword Info link if you want to go take a look. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/23/2022 I'll put another puzzle find in a reply. ....
YUP, that was a fun Monday, although could have been a Tuesday for me, as I took quite a bit longer than usual on a Monday, but seem to be the only one.

I was 36A. thinking I might get a Monday PM as I cruised through most of today's puzzle. 
Then I got the "Grrr...Almost there" message (or whatever it says).
Sure as (or a phonetic hint to 44D.) the sun rises in the east, I'd overlooked a misspelling in the northeast corner.
Tricky one!

13A,‚Äúvaluable metals‚Äù are not ‚Äúores‚Äù exactly. Ores typically contain minerals with metal elements in them (but not in metallic form/state) at high enough concentrations to be economically mined and refined.  There are a few ores that contain native metals (gold being one), but you still wouldn‚Äôt call the ore itself a valuable metal.
I won't mess about, great puzzle.  Last night also finished yesterday's which was equally fine.
nice crunchy Monday.Thanks!
a nice little monday puzzle, i feel like we all earned this after yesterday ü§£

Shaved a minute+ from my Monday average; that‚Äôs affirmative. As Monday‚Äôs go, I dug this one as it had a good beat and was danceable. 

Voiceless it cries, / Wingless flutters, / Toothless bites, / Mouthless mutters.

I took this J R R Tolkein riddle from The Hobbit. It came to my mind‚Äôs eye thanks to the overnight (and current) Middle Atlantic Coast atmosphere. It‚Äôs UNDER PRESSURE.

With Respect To George And Abe,

Bru

This is a 29A ‚Äì SMART ‚Äì puzzle.  Smart in clue, answer, and theme.

The cluing made me think, with more clue-play -- vagueness, misdirects and wordplay -- than Monday-typical.  Mondays are often rote fills for me, a veteran solver, but today I found myself going a delicious touch slower than usual.  

Lovely answers appeared along the way, such as RESOLUTE, THE WORKS, MELD, UNDER PRESSURE (a NYT debut answer), IDINA and ARETHA, NOODLING, POUNCE, EVOKES, MOROSE, and PATHOS.

And a theme whose reveal landed with a ‚ÄúWow!‚Äù and a ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù  Whose theme answers were fresh, all of them having appeared only four times or less in the NYT puzzle's 80+ years.  A theme that gave my brain the work it loves trying to guess the reveal, even though unsuccessfully.

Smart from start to finish.  A lovely first collab between you two, Katie and Erica, and I‚Äôm hoping it‚Äôs not the only.  Thank you both for a right smart Monday!

I stopped.
I collaborated.
I listened.

Oh‚Ä¶wait.

Different puzzle.

Thank you Kate and Erica!
Happy Monday all!

Solid puzzle, but seemed quite un-Mondayish to me. That said, my solve time was a bit below my Monday average. Strange.

Some interesting *words* here: RESOLUTE, MOROSE, SAVIOR, PATHOS.

TIL where they got the idea to call it a ‚Äúsmart‚Äù phone.
(Butt dialer?)

Nice puzzle, where the revealer reveals the wit.
I drink tons of red wine and have never heard of syrah. But, I'm cheap and my wine comes in a box. it's my Cardboardeaux.

Well there could be a SCRAbBOOK.......

Nice one Kate and Erica, thank you

People must be sleeping in--slow start on the Comments.

Well, this puzzle had some nice (not so common) vocabulary!  MOROSE, PAthoS, SOUGHT, RESOLUTE, NOODLING, and the clue "Staffs" for CANES, which I reall liked.

Over too soon!  How am I supposed to finish my coffee?
The first puzzle I think I‚Äôve ever done without any hint, look-up, or help! I finally feel some progress being made and like I should get a MERIT badge of my own

Nice Monday puzzle. What a relief. The crossing words revealed all the words I had trouble with. 

Congrats to the witty constructors, and "Yes. OK. Sure." to more puzzles from them.

Happy Holiday to all who have one today, and a good Monday to everyone!

OT Fun:
POUNCE reminded me of our Ohio next-door neighbors' huge black Newfooundland, Elsie, who loved to lie outside on a snowbank, surveying her kingdom.  One afternoon I had sent PhysicsDaughter over there on an errand, and when the Husand opened the front door, Elsie ran out --and (as our offspring put it, ) "POUNCED me!"  (PhysDau, being quite petite and wobbly on her best day, went flying.)  The neighbor was horrified, but Elsie's 'victim' thought it was hilarious and great fun.
I would not have thought a Newfie could "POUNCE."

I was doing fine, finished the puzzle (which was lovely), and then I got to the Constructors' notes. 

Sigh.

And so, today's ear worm will be "Down in Fraggle Rock." (Repeat.)

Nice to be surprised and amused by a Monday revealer. 

Missed opportunity to clue both Ari and Idina with something like [Wicked actress?]?

Bet we woulda had cluing like that if Lin-Manuel Miranda was in the room where it happened.

I seem to be on an emu blacklist as both my weekend comments have been lost in the ether. What did I do this time, my fowl friends?
Here goes: a good Monday, crunchier than the average for me, though no one clue stands out as being particularly difficult. 
NOODLING a new term for me and one I shall drop into conversation from now on.
UNDER PRESSURE my earworm of the day. Happy to hum it all day long. I loved Bowie‚Äôs long trench coat so much in the video I bought myself a similar one. Probably made me look foreshortened as I‚Äôm not very tall, but I felt the bees knees  in it.

OT and at the risk of being banished again; RESOLUTE raises grim memories of last week‚Äôs news.

Probably a coincidence, but it appears to be Vespa day. (See also the Mini.)
Quite a lot of food references - CHANA (masala), EGG, CANDYBAR, MAS (Taco Bell), POPEYES, DELI, THEWORKS (Everything bagel), BAO. I could even include RANCH (Dresssing, though it wasn't clued that way.) Did I miss any?
I'm going to get a loaf of bread going. Chicken Parm for supper!

Often there are complaints about cluing that skews too old (actors from long ago) or too young (modern slang). So I just wanted to give a shout out to the multigenerational cluing for 2 down üòä. Equally easy for me (Gen X, pushing 60) and my daughters (Gen Z, around 20).  Though maybe some Millenials might have found it tricky.

What a great Monday! It was fast, but didn't feel trivial and the theme was fun. Really like the alternate clue [Fragile rock?] for 9D!

Great job!

It's a tribute to the multi-culturalism of the NYT XW that entries like BAO buns and CHANA masala should appear--on a Monday!

And people may dismiss 1A, but we shouldn't underestimate Glen Bell and his franchise for introducing Mexican cuisine--even the most watered-down versions of it--to America at large, through the 1970's. Were it not for Taco Bell, we might not have fish tacos and pollo con salsa mole on every street corner.
Less of a roller coaster, more of a merry-go-round, a bit thrilling but not too chilling. Great theme and nice clueing provided a fun ride. Thanks Erica and Kate for the amusement!
Just found out how to check daily record time because I thought I might be close today. Now I‚Äôm not sure how I ever got that PR because I don‚Äôt think I will ever beat it!

If I complete it in less than an hour then I‚Äôm satisfied. It took me 42 minutes today and of course I always get more focused/motivated when there‚Äôs a theme. Thanks again and have a Marvellous Monday! Namaste!!

What a fun puzzle to start the week!  And a PB with no look ups always feels great!  

Thoroughly enjoyed the cluing today and will be hearing the incomparable Ms. Menzel and Queen+David Bowie for the rest of the day, but what great earworms!

Thanks for the great Monday puzzle, Erica and Kate.

Almost 4 minutes lower than my average Monday today! Hyped about that. Good juju heading into this week. Need an ego boost since I'm newish to the crossword. Have an awesome rest of your Monday everyone!

Nice puzzle! 

I found it had a little more challenge than many Mondays, which is nice.

Lovely Monday puzzleüòä
Thank you so much NYT for making the Mondays a little more interesting/challenging than they used to be.
Learned something new today, I've never heard of SYRAH wine! I don't drink alcohol often, so those clues always get me üòÖ

The comments section for Saturday's puzzle is closed but can I just say it was one of the worst puzzle experiences I've ever had... 

So many proper nouns and obscure trivia. I'm still at a loss for how 33A "Solid red ball" equals THREE. 

There was an abnormal amount of open-ended quote and "say" or "maybe" clues where you have to be on the constructor's exact wavelength to know what he's getting at. 

Overall the cluing just felt more mean-spirited than clever, like the constructors and editors wanted people to be frustrated. I'm all for crunchy, hard fill, especially in a themeless, but that was an absolute slog. 

9D Salty drink = SEA? I understand bodies of water are sometimes called "the drink," but the phrase doesn't work without the word "the." 

21D They cover top stories = INSULATIONS? Every story in a building is insulated. INSULATIONS isn't even a word. 

I've largely stopped commenting with criticisms but for my own sanity I had to register some protest here, that was atrocious.

Nice one, though I found it a bit challenging and tricky for a Monday.   Never heard of Syrah before, and I was far too wedded to "range" instead of "ranch" for a cowboy's workplace, for example...  (palm to forehead)    But, nice one, thank you Kate and Erica!

My usual late puzzle find. A Sunday from December 26, 2010 by Darin McDaniel with the title "Hey mister!" Some theme clue and answer examples: "The Dark Knight rooms with Quasimodo?" BATMANSINTHEBELFRY ""South Park" character leading a walk around a paddock?" CARTMANBEFORETHEHORSE "What Dustin Hoffman gets to do often, thanks to royalties?" TAKEARAINMANCHECK And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/26/2010&g=80&d=A ...

Thanks to Sam because I had AssEnT for ACCEPT and I knew that didn‚Äôt work but overlooked that I had POPEYES wrong:) I saw that C would be right to have CANES for ‚ÄúStaff‚Äù but again brute force doesn‚Äôt always help!
spot on!! if ONLY Sundays could maintain this level of goodness..
Fresh and fun. It was nice to be able to spend a tad more time with it than on some Mondays. Clever but very accessible theme. Thanks Kate and Erica üòä

I posted over the weekend about the difficulty solving the Friday puzzle on my phone. It was more trouble than I knew. Sunday, I discovered that my streak was reset to 1 and Friday's puzzle was showing as incomplete, although Saturday's was showing as solved. I wrote Game Care, am still waiting to hear back.

I think I was flyspecking as we landed. Only had one error, an oversight, fixed it (changed 5A from dUST to JUST), and got the solved message on my phone, though my sound was turned off and I heard no music. 

I think the WiFi must have turned off before I typed that letter. Turns out the timer was still running on it 2 days later and the J had reverted back to a d. 

The really puzzling thing is that I don't remember seeing anything untoward on Saturday. 

Gotta run. At a conference and going to miss my meal.

YUP this is one SMART puzzle that‚Äôs PURE fun. 
Loved NOODLING on the clues and solved with EASE at a lovely PACE. Makes me YEARN for more. PROPs to Erica and Kate, they SURE are a dream team. Please do another crossword mind MELD soon!

This was just a lovely lively puzzle! A nice crunchy Monday, and a vision of David Bowie in that trench coat to boot üòä
Thank you Kate and Erica!

@Paul 
This is a celebration of Ruggero Leoncavallo's Pagliacci aria ‚ÄúVesti la giubba,‚Äù which means "Put on the costume," modernized to "Vespa lo scooter" which could mean "Get on with the scooter," and harmless enough.
@dutchiris please clarify...are you saying that in the real world that Vespa is a pun and should be enjoyed?

@Paul 
No idea, Paul.  Just a whimsical outburst from years ago when I started to sing "Vesti la giubba" as my friend drove up on her new Vespa "scootah" (Bostonian pronunciation) (circa 1965).
@Paul So good they named it twice?

@Sam Lyons

Bowie kept churning out such excellent music. We could certainly use more like him.

Oh. I don't know. 
I think [Grande] is a nice clue change for ARI.

Wed Feb 5, 2025	
61D	Filmmaker Aster 	

Sun Feb 2, 2025
6D	Shapiro of NPR 

Thu Dec 5, 2024	
33A	Melber on MSNBC	

Tue Dec 3, 2024

etc.

etc.

@Barry Ancona 

I must agree with you, and going much staler yet, it‚Äôs all better than ‚ÄúJackie‚Äôs love‚Äù‚Ä¶
@Barry Ancona I think it's the current over use of it that's making it stale. Just like all the other names that were over used in their times.

@Gina D If by current use, you mean twice within a week, then OK. Then last time ARI was clued to the singer was on Thursday. But the time before that was in July, with eight intervening clues (see BA's post above). Then you have to go back seven more appearances before getting to the previous one in October of 2023. In fact, out of 108 clues since the first time the singer's name appeared, in 2016, only 17 have been clued to Ms. Grande, and only 6 of 30 since the beginning of 2023. To paraphrase what a different group of singers once sang, "It was just your imagination running away with you..." https://www.xwordinfo.com/Finder?w=ARI

@Lauri 

No, just one other, last Thursday.

@Wayne 
What's 'love' got to do with it?
@Steve L Twice in a week.

@kkseattle 
Unless you‚Äôre one of us who taste ammonia in Syrah/shiraz! üòú

@john ezra 
Sorry to be culturally obtuse but what is a schmear a schmear of?
I get that‚Äôs it‚Äôs something spread, apparently (only?) on a bagel, but is it always the same thing or can one schmear anything soft?
Google definitions are unhelpful

@NH 

Schmear literally means a smear or spread, but if you go into any bagel shop around here, you'd be understood to be asking for cream cheese.

@Mike 

A truly Fresh pun.

@Mike 

Really, that one should be Banned.

@Esmerelda 
Mike can ill-Lume-nate  almost any topic with his puns...

@Mike 
Roll on!
We're never going to get Arrid of this thread.
Time to Axe this topic‚Ä¶
Mike is pure inspiration.
I think you all need to Dial it back a little.

@Heidi 
You want to keep it a Secret?
These puns are Brut-al.
Here‚Äôs a link to the full Rukeyser poem: https://murielrukeyser.org/2022/02/04/yes/
@Puzzlemucker Wow that's good.
@Francis thank you so much for this!

@Sara 

Yeah, it was a pretty good, dontcha know.

@Sara 
S√≠ s√≠!

@Jane Wheelaghan 

That's why the student said "Yeah, sure."

@Steve L 
Maybe. 

But tell me, what is the meaning of 1A "Live MAS"?
I could only think of "Living mothers", Ma being what many Scots call their mother.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

MAS in Spanish is "more".

@Jane Wheelaghan 

A double negative sometimes does end up being a positive. It is not not a thing.

@Jane Wheelaghan 
I can't get no satisfaction.

Grant,

Do you try?

@Barry Ancona 
I do try, but, you see, I'm on a losing streak.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

Jay Tee covered the basics, but also:

The slogan is actually "Live M√°s"; the accent is ignored in crosswords.  But that clues you in that it's Spanish and not "mothers".  That and the fact that Taco Bell is, of course, a Mexican-ish fast food chain.  (Americans are probably at least 10 times more attuned to Spanish than Brits.)   

To further drive home the point, in commercials, the slogan is voiced over as well as superimposed on the screen; the Spanish word ends in a voiceless S sound, not the voiced Z sound that the synonym for mothers does.
@Joya Of course I filled in ohnay first, too. Rarely does the Mini have a mis-direct, but it did today. I thought it was funny.
@Eric Hougland that makes it an appropriated use for no in English. No, in piglatin would still be o-nay.

@Vaer 

The Debra Messing bit in Bros might be my favorite cameo of all time.

@Vaer 
That was a fun clue.
I watched the SNL Music special, haven't seen the Sunday special yet.
50 years of music is pretty hard to fit into 3 hours, but I really wished we'd been given a peek at Dua Lipa in that feather hat singing Levitate.

@CalGal 
I thought the music special was terrific.  Last night was a bit even for me. There were some skits that I didn't love because I never found the original material funny.

@John Carson

One of the words - the last one I got - confused me, running 3 or even 5 letters longer than I expected. I looked it up once I got it.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened: A Sunday from May 7, 2006 by Trip Payne with the title "Cue the opening." Don't think I would have had much of a chance at this one. Anyway... some clue/answer examples: "Long time that just flies by?" QUICKCENTURY "Nickname of a boxer who converted to Islam?" QURANDURAN "Bee product?" QUILTBYASSOCIATION "Grizzlies who give great interviews?" QANDABEARS And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/7/2006&g=71&d=A I'm done. ....
@NQL indeed, "valuable rocks" would be a better clue.

Steve,

Actually, no. 
Same grape, somewhat different wines.
https://www.wineenthusiast.com/culture/wine/everything-you-need-to-know-about-syrah-shiraz/ WHATEVS...
@Marcia Fidler I used to buy it.  It wasn't expensive.
OK, here‚Äôs the inside scoop. They‚Äôre basically the same thing, but SYRAH pairs well with foods served with ketchup, and Shiraz pairs well with foods served with catsup.

@Mean Old Lady 
Not much to be said about today's puzzle, I guess. To quote my mom, "Silence at the table is a compliment to the chef."
@Amy PS I did miss one thing - we can have SYRAHS with our dinner!

@Bill 
Okay, so it's the vegetarian menu items that I have trouble with, because I never order those, except for mapo dofu. Tikka masala for me, thanks, or kick it up to the vindaloo.

@Gus I turned my timer off a while back, but the website still shows your best time when you solve there and I‚Äôm always surprised by how low they are lol. I usually like to savor the puzzles so I‚Äôm betting those are me rushing to finish because I‚Äôm supposed to be doing something else in that time lol.
@Cathy   Me either!  I have heard of Shiraz, which wikipedia tells me is the same thing(?)
@Dan I think 33A is referring to a pool/billiards ball

Dan,

Sorry you weren't among the many posters in those now-closed comments who really enjoyed solving a Saturday-like Saturday puzzle.
VESPA was both in the Mini and the Crossword:)

@Lynn 

This is a good opportunity to make sure everyone knows that solves you complete on an airplane, or any other place where the WiFi might be spotty or non-existent, may not register, and you should make sure you double check this when you land or get to better internet service.

@Steve L 

Thank you, Steve, I will definitely remember that in the future.
